description:
Prometheus for system metrics. 
Load, CPU, RAM, network, process ...

panels.description: When the result is `False`, the swap is off.
panels.title: Swap Used

panels.description:
Inactive: Recently used less memory, priority to be recycled

Active: Recently used memory is not usually recycled unless absolutely necessary
panels.title: Active / Inactive

panels.description:
Writeback: Preparing to actively write back to the cache page of the hard disk

WritebackTmp: Memory used to temporarily write back to the buffer

Dirty: The data size that needs to be written back to disk
panels.title: Writeback and Dirty

panels.description:
Mapped: The memory occupied by a mapped page

Shared: The Shared memory
panels.title: Shared and Mapped

panels.description: Kernel stack size (resident memory, non-recyclable)
panels.title: KernelStack

panels.description:
AnonHugePages: The memory footprint of AnonHugePages

AnonPages: Anonymous memory page size in the user process
panels.title: Anonymous

panels.description:
HugePages_Free: The total number of idle HugePages that the system currently has

HugePages_Rsvd: The total number of HugePages currently retained by the system

HugePages_Surp: Exceeds the number of resident HugePages set by the system

HugePages: The total number of HugePages currently owned by the system
panels.title: HugePages Counter

panels.description:
Committed_AS: The amount of memory that has been allocated by the current system, including the size of the memory that has been allocated but is not yet used

CommitLimit: The amount of memory that can be allocated to the current system
panels.title: Commit

panels.description:
The rate at which data is read from the hard disk to physical memory (within 5 minutes)

Rate at which data is written from physical memory to hard disk (within 5 minutes)
panels.title: Pages In / Out

panels.description:
Rate at which data is loaded into memory from disk swap (5 minutes)

Rate at which data is dumped from memory to disk swap (within 5 minutes)
panels.title: Pages Swap In / Out

panels.description:
pgdeactivate: Average number of pages activated (within 5 minutes)

pgfree: Average number of pages released (within 5 minutes)

pgactivate: Average number of pages not activated (within 5 minutes)
panels.title: Page Operations

panels.description: Average number of pages requested to be recycled directly (within 5 minutes)
panels.title: Allocstall

panels.description:
drop_pagecache: Average number of pages called to release the cache (within 5 minutes)

drop_slab: Average number of pages to call to release the slab cache (in 5 minutes)
panels.title: Page Drop

panels.description:
pgalloc_dma: Average number of pages allocated by DMA storage area (within 5 minutes)

pgalloc_dma32: Average number of pages allocated in DMA32 storage (within 5 minutes)

pgalloc_movable: Movable storage allocated average number of pages (within 5 minutes)

pgalloc_normal: Average number of pages allocated by normal storage (within 5 minutes)
panels.title: Page Allocation

panels.description:
foreign: Plan to use other node memory but use local memory

hit: Use this node memory times

interleave: The number of times the memory of this node is used in the memory used for cross-allocation

local: The program running on this node uses the memory of this node

miss: The number of times that you plan to use this node memory to be dispatched to other nodes

other: Programs running on other nodes use the memory of this node
panels.title: Numa Allocations

panels.description:
pages_migrated: NUMA page number

Pgmigrate_fail: Number of pages failed to migrate

Pgmigrate_success: Number of pages successfully migrated
panels.title: Numa Page Migrations

panels.description:
hint_faults: NUMA hint faults trapped

hint_faults_local: Hinting faults to local nodes
panels.title: Numa Hints

panels.description:
pte_updates: NUMA page table entry updates

huge_pte_updates: NUMA huge page table entry updates
panels.title: Numa Table Updates

panels.description:
collapse_alloc: Transparent huge page collapse allocations

collapse_alloc_failed: Transparent huge page collapse allocation failures

zero_page_alloc: Transparent huge page zeroed page allocations

zero_page_alloc_failed: Transparent huge page zeroed page allocation failures

fault_alloc: Transparent huge page fault allocations

fault_fallback: Transparent huge page fault fallbacks
panels.title: THP Allocations

panels.description:
DISK seconds Read/ Write Latency.
- Critical:
  - Recommended performance value is < 10ms as avg value of the Avg Disk sec/Read,Write.
  - Critical value of the Avg Disk sec/Read,Write is > 50ms, should not exceed this value.
panels.title: Disk Write Latency (ms)

panels.description:
Disk seconds Read Latency.
- Critical:
  - Recommended performance value is < 10ms as avg value of the Avg Disk sec/Read,Write.
  - Critical value of the Avg Disk sec/Read,Write is > 50ms, should not exceed this value.
panels.title: Disk Read Latency (ms)

panels.description:
Whether an error occurred while getting statistics for the given device.
> A value > 0 Means that there are some problems with that device.
panels.title: Filesystem Device Error

panels.description:
Filesystem used space.
> If is > 80% then is Critical.
panels.title: Filesystem Space Used

panels.description:
Filesystem used file nodes.
> If is > 85% the is Critical.
panels.title: Filesystem Inodes Used

panels.description:
A file descriptor is a data structure used by a program to get a handle on a file, the most well know being 0,1,2 for standard in, standard out, and standard error.

The maximum number of file handles denotes the maximum number of open files on a Linux system.

The kernel dynamically allocates file handles whenever a file handle is requested by an application but the kernel does not free these file handles when they are released by the application. The kernel recycles these file handles instead. This means that over time the total number of allocated file handles will increase even though the number of currently used file handles may be low.

>$ cat /proc/sys/fs/file-nr

    1376    0       785623

- 1376: total allocated file descriptors (the number of file descriptors allocated since boot)
- 0: total free allocated file descriptors
- 785623: maximum open file descriptors [the maximum file handles that can be allocated (also found in /proc/sys/fs/file-max)]

1376 - 0 = 1376 (being used)
panels.title: File Descriptors Used

panels.description:
Open Files Limits.
- Critical:
   - If > 85% then there is High Usage.

process_open_fds	
>Number of open file descriptors.	

process_max_fds	
> Maximum number of open file descriptors.
panels.title: Process Open Files Used

panels.description:
Thresholds:
- Critical if state = DOWN (0)
panels.title: Network Interface State

panels.description:
Network Drops.
- Critical:
   - If  is > 0 then are Drops on that interface (IN/OUT) and is not ok.
panels.title: Network IN/OUT Drops

panels.description:
Network Errors on IN/OUT.
- Critical:
  - If Errors > 0 then there are some problems on that interface.
panels.title: Network IN/OUT Errors

panels.description:
Network Packets for IN/OUT.
- Critical:
   - If  is = 0 for IN/OUT.
panels.title: Network IN/OUT Packets

panels.description: - node_network_transmit_queue_length = transmit_queue_length value of /sys/class/net/<iface>.
panels.title: Network Interface Speed

panels.description: Number of TCP sockets in state inuse.
panels.title: TCP In Use
